node.title: Anti-vaccination Christian broadcaster dies after contracting COVID-19
node.alt: Joni and Marcus Lamb sitting on a TV couch speaking to the camera.
node.description: Founder of American religious networkÂ Daystar TV, Marcus Lamb, dies weeks after contracting COVID-19, as a review into claims of disinformation finds no breach of Australian TV codes.
node.content:
["An American televangelist accused of broadcasting COVID-19 vaccine disinformation in Australia has died, weeks after contracting the virus.", "Marcus Lamb, 64, and his wife Joni co-founded Christian TV channel Daystar in 1997. It entered the Australian TV market in 2015 through Foxtel.", "The network announced the death of Mr Lamb earlier this week on Twitter.", "\"It's with a heavy heart we announce that Marcus Lamb, president and founder of Daystar Television Network, went home to be with the Lord this morning,\" the post said.", "Mrs Lamb spoke about the death of her husband on her talk show on Tuesday morning US time.", "\"This morning at 4am, the president and founder of Daystar and the love of my life went to be with Jesus,\" she told viewers.", "\"With trying to treat COVID and the pneumonia, the different protocols that are used \u2026 it caused his blood sugar to spike, and a decrease in his oxygen.\"", "
Anti-vaccination messaging
", "The network claims to have 2 billion viewers worldwide and is available to approximately 1.7 million Australians who subscribe to Foxtel's basic package.", "Since the start of the pandemic, the Lambs have hosted interviews with controversial doctors and anti-vaccination advocates, including Robert F Kennedy Jr and Sherri Tenpenny.", "Mr Kennedy and Ms Tenpenny were this year identified in a report by the Center for Countering Digital Hate as two of the \"Disinformation Dozen\", a group of 12 people responsible for two-thirds of anti-vaccination content on social media.", "Before he died, Mr Lamb would promote the use of ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine as effective COVID-19 treatments, despite the drugs being widely discredited as such by health professionals and governments around the world.", "
Review finds no breach
", "Foxtel launched a review into the network in October, after inquiries by The Drum and members of the community.", "The review found the network did not breach any codes set out in the 2013 Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association (ASTRA) Subscription Narrowcast Television Codes of Practice.", "Foxtel explained it does not consider Daystar's talk shows to be bound by rules for news and current affairs programs.", "\"While some viewers may not agree with the comments made by the presenters and panellists during the program regarding COVID-19, nor does Foxtel condone those views, we believe the broadcast of the programs were consistent with obligations under the ASTRA Narrowcast Codes,\" a spokesperson said at the time.", "\"The ASTRA Codes also contain a provision providing that Channel Providers and Foxtel are subject to Federal and State laws when broadcasting interviews and television conversations.", "", "
A review into Daystar TV by Foxtel has not found the network to be in\u00a0breach of any Australian TV codes of conduct.(ABC News: Mark Leonardi)
", "
No TV code for disinformation
", "In February, the Australian Media and Communication Authority (ACMA) released a new Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation for online platforms, but it does not extend to television.", "Broadcasters operate under a co-regulatory system with ACMA and are responsible for initial complaints before they are referred to the media regulator.", "ACMA said it has received a response from Foxtel which it is considering.", "\"Under the co-regulatory system for broadcasting complaints, broadcasters are given the opportunity to resolve a complaint before the ACMA is involved,\" it said.", "\"Separately, the ACMA received one complaint from a viewer about a Daystar broadcast. The complainant was directed to the broadcaster in the first instance.", "\"If a complainant does not receive a response from the broadcaster within 60 days, or is not satisfied with the response they do receive, they may refer their complaint to the ACMA for consideration.\"", "", "
